content: We make scatterplots to see relationships between variables. Scatterplots are really good for helping us see if two variables have positive or negative association (or no association at all).

##Problem 1: Flower height and petal length

Sam measured the height and petal length (in centimeters) of all the flowers in his garden.  

|||||||
:-- | --: | --: | --: | --: | --: | --: 
**Height $(\text{cm})$** | $30$ | $20$ | $15$ | $35$ | $10$ | $40$ 
**Petal length $(\text{cm})$**| $6$ | $4$ | $2$ | $8$ | $1.5$ | $8.5$

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  

[[☃ graded-group 2]]  

[[☃ graded-group 3]]

options.content:
**Plot the data in a scatterplot.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hint.content:
Let's plot each point, with its $x$-coordinate coming from the *height* and the $y$-coordinate coming from the corresponding *petal length*.

**The final graph looks like this:**  

![A scatterplot plots petal length, from 0 to 10 in increments of 1, versus height, from 0 to 40 in increments of 5. Six points are plotted in a loose, diagonal cluster moving up and right as follows. (10, 1.5), (15, 2), (20, 4), (30, 6), (35, 8), (40, 8.5).](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/333b06f6d658c349663413f67435ea2d2bb5895a)

options.title: question a

options.content:
**What is the best description of the relationship between height and petal length for Sam's flowers?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hint.content:
An example of each type of association is shown below. 

$\greenD{\text{Positive association}}$  
![A scatterplot illustrating positive association shows 19 points moving upward in a loose, diagonal cluster.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2fa017d9cd398ffcc94396fb5300fb01415eb70c)

$\maroonD{\text{Negative association}}$  
![A scatterplot illustrating negative association shows 19 points moving downward in a loose, diagonal cluster.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7369fbf2eb900d2a7b7ec4f8502859ac5ef88e80)

$\goldD{\text{No association}}$  
![A scatterplot illustrating no association shows 19 points scattered wide across the graph with no discernible pattern.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/546edc63617e4a9980f6874288f4a6c949f22a9a)

**The answer for Sam's flowers:**

**Positive association**

options.title: question b

options.content:
**Which statement is the most accurate interpretation of the association?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hint.content:
We can look at it this way:

![The previous scatterplot of petal length versus height is displayed. The first three points, (10, 1.5), (15, 2), and (20, 4), are labeled short flowers, short petals. The second three points, (30, 6), (35, 8), and (40, 8.5), are labeled, tall flowers, long petals.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/016eb38387c9d8aca24ccfbb6462446da7b00352)

**The answer:**

**Taller flowers tended to have longer petals.**

options.title: question c

choices.content: Taller flowers tended to have shorter petals.
Taller flowers tended to have longer petals.
There was no clear relationship between flower height and petal length.

content:
##Problem 2: Car driver age

Data was recorded on the age of drivers and the number of car accidents per $100$ drivers in the year $2009$. The data is shown in the scatterplot below.

![A scatterplot plots Accidents per 100 drivers, from 9 to 24, in increments of 1, on the y-axis, versus Age, in years, from 16 to 25, in increments of 0.5, on the x-axis. 9 points are plotted in a loose diagonal cluster moving down and right as follows: (16, 23), (17, 20), (18, 19), (19, 15), (20, 15), (21, 14), (22, 14), (23, 17), and (24, 11). All values estimated.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ffa167e6740a1093649c055b2edff49e66268c7d)

[[☃ graded-group 4]]  

[[☃ graded-group 5]]

options.content:
**What is the best description of the relationship between age and the number of car accidents?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hint.content:
An example of each type of association is shown below. 

$\greenD{\text{Positive association}}$  
![A scatterplot illustrating positive association shows 19 points moving upward in a loose, diagonal cluster.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2fa017d9cd398ffcc94396fb5300fb01415eb70c)

$\maroonD{\text{Negative association}}$  
![A scatterplot illustrating negative association shows 19 points moving downward in a loose, diagonal cluster.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7369fbf2eb900d2a7b7ec4f8502859ac5ef88e80)

$\goldD{\text{No association}}$  
![A scatterplot illustrating no association shows 19 points scattered wide across the graph with no discernible pattern.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/546edc63617e4a9980f6874288f4a6c949f22a9a)

**The answer:**

**Negative association**

options.title: question A

options.content:
**Which statement is the most accurate interpretation of the association?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hint.content:
We can look at it this way:

![The previous scatterplot of accidents versus years is displayed. The first three points, (16, 23), (17, 20), and (18, 19), are labeled, younger drivers, more accidents. The final four, (21, 14), (22, 14), (23, 17), and (24, 11), are labeled, older drivers, fewer accidents.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/4dca991398791176acef23ae38c7c644fd139db0)

**The answer:**

**Older drivers tended to have fewer accidents.**

options.title: question b

choices.content: The older drivers tended to have fewer accidents.
The older drivers tended to have more accidents.
There was no clear relationship between age and the number of accidents.

content:
##Problem 3: Shoe sizes and test scores

Dexter's class recorded data on the test grades and shoe sizes of students in the class. The data is shown in the scatterplot below.

![A graph plots Score, from 0 to 100, in increments of 5, on the y-axis, versus Shoe size, from 0 to 11, in increments of 0.5, on the x-axis. Approximately 2 dozen points are clustered somewhat tightly together between x = 5.5 and x = 11, and between y = 52 and y = 87. All values estimated.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f6796dc096fa83db33f8cda991c286a591801f17)

[[☃ graded-group 6]]  

[[☃ graded-group 7]]

options.content:
**What is the best description of the relationship between shoe size and test scores?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hint.content:
An example of each type of association is shown below. 

$\greenD{\text{Positive association}}$  
![A scatterplot illustrating positive association shows 19 points moving upward in a loose, diagonal cluster.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2fa017d9cd398ffcc94396fb5300fb01415eb70c)

$\maroonD{\text{Negative association}}$  
![A scatterplot illustrating negative association shows 19 points moving downward in a loose, diagonal cluster.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7369fbf2eb900d2a7b7ec4f8502859ac5ef88e80)

$\goldD{\text{No association}}$  
![A scatterplot illustrating no association shows 19 points scattered wide across the graph with no discernible pattern.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/546edc63617e4a9980f6874288f4a6c949f22a9a)

**The answer:**

**No association**

options.title: question a

options.content:
**Which statement is the most accurate interpretation of the association?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hint.content:
There doesn't seem to be any association between shoe size and test scores; the scores are about as high for students with big feet as for students with small feet.

**The answer:**

**There was no clear relationship between shoe size and test scores.**

options.title: question b

choices.content: Students with bigger shoe sizes tended to score higher on the test.
Students with bigger shoe sizes tended to score lower on the test.
There was no clear relationship between shoe size and test scores.
